name: Rental unit in Vancouver · ★4.0 · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Mount Pleasant is a vibrant neighborhood nestled in the heart of Vancouver, known for its artistic flair and eclectic atmosphere. Its tree-lined streets are lined with charming heritage homes, trendy boutiques, and a wide array of restaurants and cafes.

One of the main attractions in Mount Pleasant is Main Street, a bustling hub filled with local shops, art galleries, and craft breweries. Here, you can explore unique boutiques, indulge in delicious cuisine from around the world, or simply enjoy a leisurely stroll along the vibrant streets.

name: Condo in Vancouver · ★4.92 · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview: This sweet space is situated on a pretty tree-lined street in an upcoming trendy neighbourhood.  There's a neighbourhood park which is a 5 minute walk away and features tennis courts.   In addition, Vancouver's pride and joy , Queen Elizabeth Park, is located within a mile of this cozy hideaway.   QE Park is a 130-acre municipal park. It is located on top of Little Mountain and is the location of former basalt quarries that were dug in the beginning of the twentieth century to provide material for roads in the city.  There is shopping nearby at Oakridge Shopping mall and easy access to transportation and skytrains.  The Vancouver International Airport (YVR) is a 12 minute drive.  Langara Golf Course and tennis courts are 2 minutes away by car.   If feel like walking a trail, there's one around the golf course with beautiful scenery.  Main and Fraser streets are great for grocery shopping and exotic eats!

name: Home in Vancouver · ★4.80 · 3 bedrooms · 3 beds · 2 baths
neighborhood_overview:
Nestled in the centre of Vancouver's Mount Pleasant, the neighbourhood is full of things to experience.

Steps from the front door, 10th Avenue is a beautiful tree-lined bike route that runs the entire length of Vancouver and is great for walking, running, or cycling.

Within a couple blocks there are fantastic restaurants, bars, and two 24-hour convenience stores. Walk a few more blocks and you'll have access to one of the city's nicest French restaurants, a fantastic Italian taverna, two excellent taquerias, a great pizza joint, a specialty coffee roaster, and a vegan bakery.

There are numerous parks in the area, including Vancouver's famed Dude Chilling Park (aka Guelph Park). In the summer, there's a Farmers Market at Dude Chilling Park. In the winter, there's one at the Nat Bailey Stadium, which is an 8-minute drive away.

Just beyond that, 2.5 blocks from our house is world renowned Pacific Spirit Park, which is a protected forested area of 750 hectares (1850 acres) large that borders the UBC campus, with 78 km (50 mi) of groomed trails that run all the way from the edge of Dunbar down to the beaches of Spanish Banks on English Bay. Our house is also 1/2 block from the main Dunbar shopping district, easy walking distance to all the shops: Chaldecott Walk-In Medical clinic, Shoppers Drug Mart, Dunbar Movie Theatre, Mac's Convenience Store, Stong's Grocery Store, pharmacies, restaurants, banks.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · Studio · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Kitsilano, often called "Kits," is a vibrant and trendy neighborhood located in the west side of Vancouver.
Kitsilano is known for its picturesque beaches, parks, and stunning views of the mountains and the ocean. Some of the most popular beaches in Kitsilano include Kitsilano Beach, Jericho Beach, and Spanish Banks Beach. Kitsilano Beach is particularly famous for its outdoor pool, which is open to the public from May to September each year.

The neighborhood is also home to a diverse range of shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars, many of which are located along West 4th Avenue, also known as "Kitsilano's trendy shopping district,” or West Broadway. The area is very lively with plenty of options for entertainment and socializing.

Kitsilano is a popular residential area, with a mix of heritage homes, modern condos, and apartments. It attracts a diverse population, including families, young professionals, and students from nearby universities.

neighborhood_overview:
Mount Pleasant is a neighbourhood in the city of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, stretching from Cambie Street to Clark Drive and from Great Northern Way and 2nd, to 16th and Kingsway. The neighbourhood, once characterized as working-class, has undergone a process of gentrification since the early 1990s, including the area around the Main Street and Broadway intersection.

The neighborhood is served by the Canada Line, an extension of SkyTrain from Downtown Vancouver to Vancouver International Airport.

Mount Pleasant is known as one of the more up and coming neighbourhoods, especially in the communities surrounding Vancouver's downtown peninsula. Many first-time homeowners and young professionals, as well as a growing number of families, call Mount Pleasant home.

neighborhood_overview:
In the 1960s, beachside Kitsilano was Vancouver's hippy hangout, drawing comparisons to San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury.

Today, Kitsilano still has plenty of culture, but its apartments and houses are now occupied by young urban professionals and families who enjoy a modern version of that relaxed atmosphere – this is the birthplace of global yoga brand, lululemon athletica. Just over the Burrard Bridge from the downtown peninsula, the neighbourhood brings together a collection of attractions, beach and parks, residential streets, and a couple of main commercial districts. “Kits,” as it’s known locally, is bordered by the waterfront to the north and West 16th Ave to the south; Burrard Street to the east and Alma Street to the west. Most of the commercial activity is along West 4th Avenue and West Broadway, but you’ll also find shops and restaurants in the areas close to the beach.

neighborhood_overview:
One of Vancouver's most popular neighbourhoods, Kitsilano is central to beaches, shops/cafes and downtown.

Named for Khatsahlanough, a Squamish Nation chief, Kitsilano's storied past includes being a hippie and counterculture haven in the 1960’s and 70’s and the home of both Greenpeace, founded in 1975, and the BC Green Party, founded in 1983.

Today’s Kits is a combination of the eco- and hippie-spirit of its past and 21st century gentrification, emblematized in the neighbourhood’s organic markets, multicultural restaurants, and shops like Lululemon, Vancouver’s famous yoga-wear chain.

A beach in British Columbia has been named one of the best in Canada, and it’s right here in Vancouver.

Travel publisher Lonely Planet has released its list of the top 10 beaches in the country, and BC has come up swimmingly.

Instead of ranking each beach from one to 10, though, each sandy spot has been given its own “best of” title.

Vancouver’s own Kitsilano Beach, located in its namesake neighbourhood, has been crowned the best urban beach in Canada.

“Backed by cool cafes and an attractive park, Kits exudes a sporty, laid-back vibe, especially in summer.”

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · ★4.63 · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
A beach in British Columbia has been named one of the best in Canada, and it’s right here in Vancouver.

Travel publisher Lonely Planet has released its list of the top 10 beaches in the country, and BC has come up swimmingly.

Instead of ranking each beach from one to 10, though, each sandy spot has been given its own “best of” title.

Vancouver’s own Kitsilano Beach, located in its namesake neighbourhood, has been crowned the best urban beach in Canada.


“A freewheeling nugget of Southern California chopped off and transported one thousand miles north,” Lonely Planet writes. “The yellow arc of sand is sugary and clean.”

“Backed by cool cafes and an attractive park, Kits exudes a sporty, laid-back vibe, especially in summer.”

The publisher highlights the beach’s breathtaking views, as well as its ample options for leisure sports – from volleyball nets to grassy expanses that beg for a game of football.

neighborhood_overview:
Commercial Drive is a neighbourhood like none other. Located on the East side of Vancouver, Commercial Drive was known as "Little Italy." The colourful shops, some owned by the original families, still exist from that era. Along "the Drive," as it’s called affectionately by Vancouverites, are local independent shops filling any need you might have.

The area has become filled with arts and culture in recent years. Artist's studios exist throughout the neighbourhood and local live theatre, art exhibitions and shops cover the area. Commercial Drive was historically one of the upscale neighbourhoods of Vancouver, with many heritage mansions and architecture built during the Edwardian era.

neighborhood_overview: East Vancouver, or East Van encompasses the area east of Main Street. Main Street begins in Gastown, runs through Chinatown and the Downtown Eastside, and continues running south. It is a mecca of fashion, art, and design boutiques, as well as a diverse and affordable area for groceries, restaurants, and cafes. This is Vancouver’s go-to place for local artists and designers. Commercial Drive, known as “The Drive”, is an area in East Van close to Downtown. With the Commercial-Broadway SkyTrain station, and several high-frequency bus routes, it is well-served by public transit.

name: Home in Vancouver · ★4.67 · 2 bedrooms · 2 beds · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
East Vancouver’s Commercial Drive is a thriving artist and foody neighbourhood.

A culturally rich and authentic neighbourhood, Commercial Drive - also known as The Drive - is one of the best and most colourful shopping, dining and nightlife districts you will find in the city; and boasts home to Vancouver’s own 8 block Little Italy, representing more than 60 years of Italian heritage. Day or evening, The Drive offers 22 full blocks to explore with over 300 distinct merchants, including quaint boutiques, an eclectic collection of restaurants, a vibrant live music and bar scene, dinner and dancing, theatres, coffee houses, specialty food stores and bakeries. A one of a kind experience. Welcome to The Drive.

name: Home in Vancouver · ★4.96 · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
The Strathcona neighbourhood is known for its historical and cultural heritage, diverse architecture, and vibrant community. It is located east of downtown and has a mix of residential and commercial properties. The neighborhood is known for its vibrant arts scene, unique local businesses, and diverse population.

Today, Strathcona is defined by its long history and rapid development. Burrard inlet is to north, Clark Drive to the east, False Creek to the south, and Chinatown to the west.

Strathcona neighbours the Downtown Eastside. In recent years, the Downtown Eastside has struggled with many complex challenges including a rise in drug use, homelessness, and housing issues. The area is safe, and there is a large police presence.

Community Awareness in Vancouver: Compassion and Caution

In Vancouver, like many cities, homelessness is a part of daily life. Treat everyone with dignity, as small acts of kindness can make a big difference. Remember, "The things you keep forever are the things you give away for nothing."

While exploring, be aware and follow your instincts. Kindness matters, but also exercise caution around aggressive behavior. Your safety matters.

name: Condo in Vancouver · 2 bedrooms · 4 beds · 2.5 baths
neighborhood_overview:
Location

Tucked up against the waterfront of Vancouver, Coal Harbour is bordered by Denman Street at the north, Georgia Street on the west, Burrard Street on the south and the Vancouver harbour to the east. This neighbourhood includes not only luxury housing but also a vibrant working harbour with its float plane terminal, Convention Centre and Cruise Ship Terminal. Stanley Park sits at the northern edge and the financial district of Vancouver borders its southern area. To the east you can see Deadman’s Island which is the site of a naval station and museum and where the harbour opens up to the Burrard Inlet. The discovery of coal in the harbour area in 1862 is what led to its iconic name.

Housing and History

name: Condo in Vancouver · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Heritage neighborhood meets modern lifestyle describes the historic district of Yaletown. Originally the 1886 western terminus of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the brick wall warehouse district of Yaletown is presently both a vibrant and walkable district, making the gleaming residential towers surrounding the area some of the most coveted in the city.

Yaletown provides the serenity of an oceanfront seawall, along with the largest selection of trendy patios and award-winning boutiques.

As a great escape within the big city, Yaletown offers an opportunity to explore acclaimed restaurants and eclectic shops set along heritage brick walkways.

Vancouver's vibrant West End is located at the west end of downtown Vancouver, just east of Stanley Park and Lost Lagoon. The West End is surrounded by water on three sides: English Bay, Coal Harbour, and Lost Lagoon in world-famous Stanley Park.

Safeway and Whole Foods are both within a two-minute / 140m / .08mi walk from the building's front door.

The West End is the heart of Vancouver's LGBTQ2S+ community, including Davie Village and Denman Street, which together provide local shopping and restaurants. This area also has high-end retail and boutique shopping on Robson Street and Alberni Street. The night life, movie theatres, and intimate concert venues on Granville Street are just a 20 minute / 1.7km / 1mi walk away.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · ★4.95 · 4 bedrooms · 5 beds · 2 baths
neighborhood_overview: Mount Pleasant is the hip and happening spot in Vancouver! Centrally located and a walkers paradise. If you're looking for an authentic, vibrant neighbourhood in Vancouver to explore aimlessly for an afternoon of window shopping, eating and drinking - a blend of cool, independent, unique-to-Vancouver stores, restaurants, cafes, craft breweries, live music venues, amazing murals, used record stores, quirky gift shops, used book shops and side streets lined with heritage houses and lush gardens - Mount Pleasant is your place. The locals argue that it's the best shopping area in the city these days and if you love food this is the place to be with outstanding restaurants. It's also a fun area in the evening if you're looking for small scale nightlife. If you enjoy art then download our local mural walking tour and check out our amazing Mount Pleasant murals or try out the local craft beer!

neighborhood_overview:
Commercial Drive is a neighbourhood like none other. Located on the East Side of Vancouver, Commercial Drive is also known as "Little Italy”
from the time it was dominated by Italian merchants. Now the mix is more broad, but the colourful heritage shops, some owned by the original families, still exist. Along "the Drive," as it’s called affectionately by Vancouverites, are local independent shops filling any need you might have.

The area has become filled with arts and culture in recent years. Artist's studios exist throughout the neighbourhood and local live theatre, art exhibitions and shops cover the area. Commercial Drive was historically one of the upscale neighbourhoods of Vancouver, with many heritage mansions and buildings built during the Edwardian era.

West Point Grey runs along English Bay, between the University of British Columbia and Kitsilano. A neighbourhood on the western side of the city of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Vancouver's West End is a vibrant and diverse neighborhood located on the western edge of downtown Vancouver. Known for its beautiful beaches, stunning views, and abundance of green space, the West End is a popular destination for both locals and visitors alike.

The West End is such a great neighborhood and has some amazing things to see and do.

Visit English Bay Beach: This popular beach is located on the northern edge of the West End and is known for its beautiful sunsets and clear waters. It's a great spot for swimming, sunbathing, and beach volleyball.

Explore Stanley Park: This huge urban park is located at the western tip of the West End and is home to a variety of recreational activities, including hiking and biking trails, an aquarium, and a miniature train.

Walk along the Seawall: The Seawall is a popular walking and biking path that winds around Stanley Park and offers stunning views of the ocean and the city.

name: Boutique hotel in Vancouver · ★4.68 · 2 bedrooms · 2 beds · 2 baths
neighborhood_overview:
The Yaletown area basically encompasses the north side of the False Creek Waterway. The original site of Vancouver lumberyards and industrial mills, the area was cleaned up and became the renowned Expo 86 site when Vancouver hosted the world. Since Expo 86, the 204 acres have been carefully transformed into an urban residential oasis that combines the best of the waterfront with the vibrancy of the urban atmosphere.

A necklace of parks adorns the area around the False Creek basin including David Lam, Creekside and Coopers’ Parks.

Take the time and visit David Lam Park, an impressive 10 acres of open green space and flowers. The beautiful David Lam Park is named for an extraordinary public figure who retired after an illustrious 6-year term as British Columbia’s Lieutenant Governor. David Lam Park is a great place for children. Two large play areas provide hours of fun. A plaza steps down to a natural grass playing field and a tidal pool surrounded by large boulder

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Sunlight filters in through the floor-to-ceiling windows, warming the latte tones and golden hues around you. Basking in complete ease, you contemplate your day ahead from the cosy comfort of your room at Shangri-La Private Residence, Vancouver.
As you tuck into a sumptuous breakfast, a sweeping view of the vibrant metropolis that is Vancouver unfolds before you. Settling into your tastefully furnished surroundings, you catch a glimpse of the majestic firs of Stanley Park in the distance. A leisurely stroll along the sapphire blue waters of its lakes would be heavenly.

You decide on a short drive to Grouse Mountain. You're in the right season for helicopter rides, and skiing and snowboarding off its slopes. The rush of height and speed proves refreshingly exhilarating.

Nestled between the Coast Mountain Range and the Pacific Ocean. You plan to take it a day at a time. For now, Shangri-La Hotel, Vancouver, beckons.
You head straight for CHI, The Spa.

It's the liveliest area of greater Vancouver; if you’re looking for a quiet home on a weekend, look somewhere else, but if you love energy and being at the epicenter of all that's happening, this is the home away from home for you!

While everything is at your fingertips in this neighborhood, my home is stocked with absolutely anything your family may need for a weekend or a long-term stay, so pack light!

neighborhood_overview:
Welcome to our vibrant neighborhood in beautiful Vancouver, BC! Nestled in the heart of the city, our location offers convenient access to all the exciting attractions and amenities that this cosmopolitan area has to offer.

As you explore the neighborhood, you may encounter individuals who are struggling with addiction or experiencing homelessness. It's important to note that Vancouver has taken progressive steps towards supporting these individuals by decriminalizing street drugs. This approach prioritizes harm reduction and access to support services, fostering a compassionate community.

In spite of these challenges, our neighborhood remains a lively and energetic place. You'll find a dynamic mix of local businesses, charming cafes, eclectic shops, and a diverse culinary scene right at your doorstep. Immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere as you stroll through the bustling streets, where you'll discover a rich tapestry of cultures and experiences.

This trendy neighborhood is within close proximity to BC Place Stadium, Stanley Park, Rogers Arena, Vancouver Convention Center, and more. It is sure to meet the needs of both the business and leisure traveler.

neighborhood_overview:
Discover the vibrant heart of Vancouver in the historic Gastown district. Our neighborhood, named after the 19th-century saloon owner "Gassy" Jack Deighton, boasts a unique blend of history and modernity, characterized by Victorian architecture and cobblestone streets. You'll find the iconic steam clock, a marvel of engineering, just steps away.

Gastown's charm extends beyond its rich past. Our streets brim with an array of trendy boutiques, unique galleries, and gourmet restaurants, creating a hub for art, culture, and food. From your doorstep, you can explore a tapestry of local businesses that showcase the best of what Vancouver has to offer.

The area is as dynamic as it is diverse. Like many urban centers, Gastown faces challenges related to homelessness, primarily due to its proximity to the Downtown Eastside. Local organizations and community initiatives are actively working towards sustainable solutions, with an emphasis on social inclusion.

neighborhood_overview:
Main Street is a north-south linear amalgam of Mount Pleasant/Riley Park/Little Mountain, a contiguous high street entity. It boasts beautiful parks both small and large, a dizzying variety of retail shops (many of them used/vintage), a handful of art galleries, a torrent of new breweries, good record stores, a litter of interesting independent restaurants that run the cuisine gamut, quality cafes/hangouts, live music venues, bingo games, a happening legion, and even a farmer’s market. Known as much for its cool factor as for its diversity and down-to-earth accessibility, Main Street – in our estimation of its modern borders – is as honest a cross-sectioned representation of Vancouver’s cultural promise as you’ll find.

Point Grey Village serves as the area's shopping district, where many independently owned businesses contribute to a village-like atmosphere.

West Point Grey runs along English Bay, between the University of British Columbia and Kitsilano. A neighbourhood on the western side of the city of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. It is bordered by 16th Avenue to the south, Alma Street to the east, English Bay to the north, and Blanca Street to the west.

Today, it's one of Canada's most expensive residential areas. Vancouver has an amazing restaurant scene where many are quite affordable.

The house is 15 minutes from the airport and 20 minutes to downtown Vancouver. Highway 91, highway 99 and Richmond are easily accessible.

If you will be travelling by public transit:
There is a bus stop right in front of the house. The proximity of the house to the bus stop makes public transit very convenient for commuting within Vancouver. G oogle maps or the TransLink website can be used for trip planning and times.

There is a direct bus route #22 Downtown/Knight to downtown from the bus stop in front of the house. This bus takes you directly to downtown. It will also take you directly to University Canada West (Pender Campus). neighborhood_overview:
The Drive: What can we say?! We love The Drive. It's unique in that it's such a mix of cultures. So many friendly people and good energy. It's also a wonderful place for affordable food shopping and there are a huge array of restaurants with several great Italian restaurants and Sushi places within a couple of block from where we live. Recently a few new amazing eateries have popped up within 2 blocks from where we live including an a fantastic bakery called Livia at Commercial Drive and Kitchener (very close!) a bagelry, and a new Italian restaurant called Sopra Sotto just at the corner. We highly recommend them all.

Parking:
Parking is frequently available in marked spots across the street from our place and around the corner on Cotton Drive. Please remember to park ONLY in areas that are not described as Permit Parking.

We like to remind people that the spot just next to our driveway, and in front of our home, is "No Stopping".

name: Condo in Vancouver · ★5.0 · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
Live downtown in one of the safest and trendiest neighborhoods. Yaletown is home to some of the best dining options in Vancouver, making it easy to stroll the area first before choosing a café or restaurant. It is one of the best places to spend an evening with its active cocktail scene and nightlife — luxe lounges, lively neighborhood pubs and boutique clubs.

Parks and False Creek are right at your doorstep. The seawall runs right along the water, connecting two of the biggest green spaces: David Lam Park and George Wainborn Park.

The neighborhood boasts numerous quirky and stylish locally-owned designer stores. Conveniently linked by skytrain, you can also catch the Aquabus to Granville Island for a day trip. Condo is at Homer St & Drake St intersection.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · ★New · 1 bedroom · 1 bed · 1 bath

neighborhood_overview:
Nestled in Vancouver's historic heart lies Gastown, a neighborhood rich with Victorian architecture, cobblestone streets, and the iconic steam clock. A blend of past and present, Gastown offers an unforgettable cultural experience, showcasing trendy boutiques, unique art galleries, and a culinary scene that's second to none.

Situated at 333 Carrall Street in vibrant Gastown, our establishment offers 24/7 security monitoring and an attentive on-site staff to ensure your safety and comfort. While the neighborhood's close proximity to the Downtown Eastside brings a notable presence of homelessness, we've taken comprehensive measures to create a secure environment for our guests. As you explore the local culture, nearby attractions, or unwind with our amenities, rest assured that your well-being is our top priority. Your peace of mind is integral to your experience here, and we're committed to providing it despite the neighborhood's unique challenges.
Named after the legend

neighborhood_overview: Le Soleil Hotel and Suites is situated in the heart of Vancouver's hotel and entertainment district and is steps away from restaurants, shopping, and transportation services. The building is a 5-minute walk (370m) from the Vancouver Convention Centre and a 4-minute walk (300m) from the Vancouver Art Gallery and Pacific Centre Mall. The Burrard Skytrain Station, Canada Place, Coal Harbour, and the Sea Wall are just steps away. Slightly further out you will find historic Gastown, the Robson shopping district, the charming West End, Stanley Park and many beautiful beaches. There is also no limit to the delicious food and drink that can be found in the many eateries downtown. Alouette French Bistro is located next to the hotel lobby, offering a selection of à la carte breakfast, lunch, and dinner options. Vancouver International Airport (YVR) is located 15 away and is accessible from the hotel by either a 20-minute taxi ride or a 30-minute skytrain ride from nearby stations.

This fast and frequent service offers a very easy way to explore the heart of Vancouver without the need to drive or find parking.

In addition to the SkyTrain, several bus routes serve our neighborhood. The #41 and #43 buses run east-west along 41st Avenue, while the #17 bus runs north-south along Oak Street. All these lines offer convenient access to various parts of the city.

Whether you're seeking vibrant nightlife, unique shopping experiences, or a glimpse into Vancouver's past, Gastown has it all. Book your stay in this dynamic neighborhood and immerse yourself in the rich tapestry of Vancouver's history, culture, and contemporary charm.

At the tip of the West End lies the iconic Stanley Park, a sprawling urban oasis boasting a temperate rainforest, lush vegetation, meandering paths, and postcard-worthy vistas. Just moments from your B&B, this majestic park invites exploration along its scenic Seawall, with panoramic views of English Bay and the North Shore Mountains.

Immerse yourself in the coastal appeal of English Bay, mere steps from your accommodation. The gentle waves create an idyllic setting for leisurely strolls or tranquil moments soaking in the Pacific's beauty. name: Home in Vancouver · 5 bedrooms · 6 beds · 6.5 baths

neighborhood_overview:
Despite the fact that Coal Harbour is right downtown, it’s a surprisingly calm little neighbourhood, right on the water’s edge. It’s even more surprising given its industrial history as a former shipyard sitting right next to the railway terminus. The area starts at Canada Place and stretches west to Stanley Park, and is bordered by Burrard Inlet to the north, West Georgia Street to the south. Coal Harbour is a charming mix of business and residential, being home to both the Vancouver Convention Centre as well as condo towers. Around this area you’ll find locals and visitors mingling on the Seawall, neighbourhood cafes and restaurants, a popular marina, and the odd harbour seal bobbing around and greeting passersby.

Seeing and Doing
Even if you’re not visiting on business, a walk around the Vancouver Convention Centre is recommended. Along with lots of public art, the surrounding section of the seawall includes many interpretive plaques giving visitors a sense of the ha

neighborhood_overview:
Stathcona is Vancouver's oldest neighborhood, characterized by colorful heritage homes that set it apart in our gleamingly modern city of glass. Home to dozens of artist's studios, it's the nucleus of the creative community and a hub for innovators of all stripes. Many of the craftsman-style cottages that were built a century ago by workers in the nearby port are now occupied by young families—the playground across the street from our home is always packed!

Proximity to Gastown, Railtown, and Chinatown, with all their shopping and dining opportunities, is one of Strathcona's top advantages. This also means proximity to the Downtown Eastside, with all its various sights and sounds.

Many residents (ourselves included) say the close-knit community among neighbors are Strathcona's greatest asset, so strike up a conversation at one of the many local cafes to get to know the neighborhood better. You can also check out this neighborhood guide from a local indie publica

Nestled in the eastern part of the city, this neighborhood is characterized by its rich cultural diversity and a mix of residential, commercial, and green spaces.

Renfrew-Collingwood boasts a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere, making it a popular destination for families, professionals, and individuals of all backgrounds. The area is home to a variety of cultural festivals, markets, and events that celebrate its multicultural identity. This inclusivity is reflected in the diverse range of dining options, with international cuisines from around the world available within walking distance.

The neighborhood's architecture is a mix of older heritage homes, mid-century structures, and newer developments. Its tree-lined streets and local parks provide a peaceful contrast to the bustling urban life. Central Park, a spacious

Tangent has a fun mix of pub food classics and amazing Malaysian food (the head chef grew up in Malaysian Borneo), the best of the city's craft beer on tap (try the Dageraad - the brewer is also a dear friend of ours!), and some of the country's best jazz music every Thursday night and Sunday afternoon.

More information

neighborhood_overview: Gastown is a neighbourhood that seamlessly combines old with new, history with the way forward. Continue to the end of Water Street to visit a statue of the man who started it all, Gassy Jack Deighton. Architecture and history buffs can take organized walking tours of the area to further explore. Get a bird’s eye view of the area from the Vancouver Lookout, which rises 167-metres (548-feet) to give visitors a 360˚ panorama of the city.

name: Guest suite in Vancouver · ★4.77 · 2 bedrooms · 2 beds · 1 bath
neighborhood_overview:
In the 1960s, beachside Kitsilano was Vancouver's hippy hangout, drawing comparisons to San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury.

Today, Kitsilano still has plenty of culture, but its apartments and houses are now occupied by young urban professionals and families who enjoy a modern version of that relaxed atmosphere – this is the birthplace of global yoga brand, lululemon athletica. Just over the Burrard Bridge from the downtown peninsula, the neighborhood brings together a collection of attractions, beach and parks, residential streets, and a couple of main commercial districts. “Kits,” as it’s known locally, is bordered by the waterfront to the north and West 16th Ave to the south; Burrard Street to the east and Alma Street to the west. Most of the commercial activity is along West 4th Avenue and West Broadway, but you’ll also find shops and restaurants in the areas close to the beach.

The waterfront parks are a big draw in Yaletown. The city’s seawall runs right along the water, connecting two of the biggest green spaces: David Lam Park and George Wainborn Park. Walk, jog, bike or inline skate along the Seawall and you’ll find plenty of locals doing the same and enjoying the excellent public art sprinkled along the waterfront.

Knight Street is a major thoroughfare in Vancouver, British Columbia, running predominantly in a north-south direction.
Along Knight Street and in the nearby areas, you'll find a range of local businesses, shops, restaurants, cafes, and small retail outlets.
Knight Street is a significant transportation route, providing good connectivity to other parts of the city and major highways.
The community along Knight Street is generally known for its welcoming and friendly atmosphere.

neighborhood_overview:
41st Avenue and Victoria Street find themselves in the heart of Vancouver, a city steeped in history and cultural significance. The region was once home to indigenous communities like the Musqueam, Squamish, and Tsleil-Waututh Nations, whose presence can still be felt in the area's landmarks and place names.

One of the defining features of this neighborhood is its cultural diversity. A melting pot of various ethnicities, it celebrates a tapestry of traditions, languages, and cuisines. Walking along 41st Avenue and Victoria Street, one can encounter a delightful array of restaurants, shops, and markets offering delicacies from around the globe.

As a microcosm of Vancouver's charm and character, this thriving urban hub continues to captivate the hearts of those who call it home or simply visit to experience its unique magic.

neighborhood_overview: Kitsilano is a quiet, family oriented, beachside neighbourhood very close to downtown. We are within walking distance to two amazing beaches, Kits Beach and Jericho beach. You can paddle board at Jericho sailing club and perhaps spot a harbour seal or whale (if you're lucky) in English Bay or swim at the oceanside Kits beach pool. Kitsilano is traditionally the city's Greek neighbourhood and is home to an annual Greek Days at the end of June.Many local vendors sell fresh produce both organic and non organic. The Kitsilano farmers market every Sunday is one of the city's largest markets and is filled with fabulous vendors selling produce, meats, and baked goods as well as always a few local beverage producers with beer, wine and spirits. There are multiple bakeries and coffee shops nearby as well as some of the cities highest rated farm to table restaurants. As well, there is a multiplex cinema, a Starbucks, and other cafes and services. There is also another large supermarket a short distance east, at Main Street and SW Marine Drive.

neighborhood_overview:
Hastings-Sunrise is a residential area with a busy mix of Asian eateries, cozy bakeries and family-run shops along East Hastings Street. It’s also home to Hastings Park, site of the annual Pacific National Exhibition summer fair, featuring rock concerts, thrill rides and agricultural shows. Just a stone's throw away is Gastown, a historic district renowned for its cobblestone streets, trendy boutiques, and vibrant nightlife.

Back in Strathcona, you can meander through its beautifully preserved heritage houses, visit local parks like MacLean Park, or indulge in artisanal coffee shops and cozy eateries. With easy access to downtown Vancouver, Strathcona provides a perfect blend of tranquility and proximity to the city's buzzing core.

Within 2 blocks there are fantastic sushi, gourmet pizza, and Ethiopian restaurants, and two 24-hour convenience stores. There is also a local watering hole that often offers live music.

Walk 3 more blocks and you'll have access to one of the city's best French restaurants, a family-friendly sports bar, two excellent taquerias, a specialty coffee roaster, and a vegan bakery. Here you will also find a bar that is modeled after the 90's TV show Twin Peaks!

It has undergone many changes in the 20th century, with the influx of traffic and development associated with the construction of the Oak Street Bridge (which leads to Highway 99 leading to the southern suburbs) and the Arthur Laing Bridge (which leads to Vancouver International Airport).

Coal Harbour is a beautiful and vibrant neighborhood located in the heart of downtown Vancouver, British Columbia. This area offers stunning views of the Burrard Inlet, the North Shore Mountains, and Stanley Park, making it a popular destination for both locals and visitors alike.

It's an excellent location for guests who want to explore the city and enjoy the beautiful scenery. The neighborhood is home to many world-class attractions, including the Vancouver Convention Centre, the Vancouver Aquarium, and the iconic Seawall.

Additionally, Coal Harbour offers plenty of outdoor activities, from hiking and biking in Stanley Park to water sports and boating in the marinas and yacht clubs. The area also has many fine dining options, boutique shops, and entertainment venues within walking distance.

neighborhood_overview:
Gastown is a charming and historic neighbourhood located in the heart of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. It is often considered the birthplace of the city and is known for its unique blend of old-world charm and modern amenities. Here's some more information about this iconic area:

History: Gastown was established in 1867 by John "Gassy Jack" Deighton, a steamboat captain. He opened the area's first saloon, which quickly became a popular gathering spot. The town grew around this saloon and eventually became the city of Vancouver. The famous Gastown Steam Clock, located at the corner of Water Street and Cambie Street, is a beloved symbol of the neighbourhood's history.

Architecture: Gastown's architecture is characterized by its well-preserved heritage brick buildings. Cobblestone streets, wrought-iron lampposts, and a mix of Victorian and Edwardian architecture create a unique and picturesque atmosphere. Many of these buildings have been repurposed into bouti

Yaletown is the most walkable mixed commercial-residential district in Greater Vancouver. In fact, WalkScore gives it a 96/100 officially designating it to be a “Walker's Paradise”. That said, you need access to public transit too, which is where the area really shines.

The Marpole district is a peaceful, predominantly residential area that is also home to a number of shops as cafes, eateries, and stores. Notable places include The Yard Café, known for its breakfast, brunch, and lunch offerings, and Gigi Blin, an informal Italian eatery renowned for its wood-fired pizzas and homemade pastas.

In addition, the Marpole district is in close proximity to several attractions like the VanDusen Botanical Garden, home to a diverse array of global flora, and the Marpole-Oakridge Community Centre, equipped with a pool, gym, and other facilities. There are several parks and areas along the river that are popular for fishing, parks and zones by the river, such as Fraser River Park and Marpole Park, are favored for fishing. A valid fishing license is required for all fishing activities.

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · 2 bedrooms · 3 beds · 2.5 baths
neighborhood_overview:
Yaletown was once the Western terminus for the Canadian Pacific Railway, but the area’s more recent reinvention dates back to 1986 when the waterfront along the north of False Creek was host to many of the venues when Vancouver hosted the World’s Fair. Since then that land, along with the warehouse district adjoining it have been transformed into one of the city’s chicest neighbourhoods, filled with residential loft spaces, sidewalk cafes, cool restaurants, unique shopping, and leafy parks. Sitting along the south side of the downtown Vancouver peninsula, Yaletown is bordered by Homer Street, Robson Street and False Creek.

The waterfront parks are a big draw in Yaletown. The city’s seawall runs right along the water, connecting two of the biggest green spaces: David Lam Park and George Wainborn Park. Walk, jog, bike or inline skate along the Seawall and you’ll find plenty of locals doing the same and enjoying the excellent public art sprinkled along the waterfront. The neigh

name: Rental unit in Vancouver · 3 bedrooms · 3 beds · 2 baths

Vancouver’s business and retail core is where the action happens and is extremely walkable. Here is where you can navigate the sidewalks packed with people in suits, while admiring the shiny glass architecture. Downtown Vancity is home to the retail hubs of Robson Street, Pacific Centre, and Nordstrom. Business is bustling in skyscrapers such as the Bentall Centre and Telus Garden, and tourists and locals are aplenty at the Canada Place cruise ship terminal and grass-roofed Convention Centre. Don’t forget Vancouver’s OG party street with the nightclubs locals love to hate (and always end up at the end of the night) – the Granville Street strip.
As in most cities, downtown Vancouver is a great place to kick off your tour of the city and get the lay of the land.

neighborhood_overview:
Strathcona is one of this city's earliest neighbourhoods. It features beautifully restored row houses, overflowing flower gardens, and welcoming front porches. It has one of the largest concentrations of 19th and early 20th century buildings in Vancouver.

Strathcona grew out of the collection of shacks and small buildings that surrounded the Hastings Mill site, and has a unique mix of people, history, land use, and architecture.

It is a neighbourhood of houses, apartment buildings, and rooming houses where neighbours walk to the corner store, do tai chi in the parks or stroll in the community garden. It is a community that has managed to survive, and thrive, despite constant pressure for change.

neighborhood_overview:
Kitsilano, often called "Kits," is a vibrant and trendy neighborhood located in the west side of Vancouver. This unit is conveniently located 1 block from Kitsilano beach and its amenities!

Kitsilano is known for its picturesque beaches, parks, and stunning views of the mountains and the ocean. Some of the most popular beaches in Kitsilano include Kitsilano Beach, Jericho Beach, and Spanish Banks Beach. Kitsilano Beach is particularly famous for its outdoor pool, which is open to the public from May to September each year.

The neighborhood is also home to a diverse range of shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars, many of which are located along West 4th Avenue, also known as "Kitsilano's trendy shopping district,” or West Broadway. The area is very lively with plenty of options for entertainment and socializing.
